cover.intro: The first setup steps that shape branding, user identity, and language for the whole platform.
takeaways: Set company profile once; it appears across the system
User profile controls identity and role
Language options can be managed over time
Homepage gives a category-based document overview

cards.title: Homepage: Documents by Category
cards.why: A quick overview of document distribution across categories when you log in.
body: The homepage displays document statistics organized by category, showing the total count per category.
Use it as your dashboard overview every time you log in — at a glance you can see which departments have the most or fewest files.

cards.title: Company Profile
cards.why: Your branding and name appear across the platform (including login screen).

tables.title: Company Profile Fields
rows: 2–50 characters. Appears as browser tab title.
PNG/JPG/JPEG, max 2 MB. Recommended: 200×100px. Shown in login page header.
PNG/JPG/JPEG, max 3 MB. Recommended: 1200×300px. Shown on login screen below header.

notes: The company name you enter here will appear dynamically as the browser tab title across the entire platform.

cards.title: Your User Profile
cards.why: Manage your identity and account settings; administrators assign roles.

tables.title: User Profile Fields
rows: Your given name used throughout the platform.
Your family name used throughout the platform.
Your login email and main notification address.
Set or update your account password.
Assigned by admin; controls feature access.

notes: Fields with errors are highlighted with inline messages. Click Submit once all required fields are filled in correctly.

cards.title: Language Settings
cards.why: Control the languages available in the platform interface.

body: Administrators can add, update, and remove language options at any time.
Users interact with the full platform in their configured language.

cover.intro: Create accounts, define roles, assign permissions, and manage the client directory.
takeaways: Users get roles; roles bundle permissions
Drag-and-drop can assign users to roles
Individual permissions override role defaults when needed
Clients directory helps organize external parties

cards.title: Users
cards.why: Create and manage user accounts and access levels.

bullets: Control access via roles and permissions

cards.title: Roles
cards.why: Bundle permissions into reusable access profiles.

steps: Name the role clearly (e.g., Reviewer, Manager).
notes: Permissions can include: view, edit, delete, share documents; manage users; define categories; sign documents; and more.

cards.title: Assigning Roles to Users
cards.why: Quickly attach users to roles using a visual list workflow.

steps: Find the role you want to assign.
Drag a user from **All Users** (left) to **Users with Role** (right).
Drop the user to assign them; repeat as needed.
notes: Use your mouse or touch device: drag a user from the All Users list on the left and drop them into the Users with Role list on the right.

cards.title: Individual User Permissions
cards.why: Grant one-off access without creating a whole new role.

body: This is useful when a user occasionally needs access to a feature not covered by their role — without creating an entirely new role just for them.

cards.title: Clients Directory
cards.why: Organize external parties for sharing, requests, and communication.

cover.intro: Browse, filter, and act on documents. This is the operational center of the platform.
takeaways: All Documents is the master library
Assigned Documents is your personal workload
Archive keeps history without clutter
Expired documents are clearly flagged

cards.title: All Documents
cards.why: Search, filter, and run actions on any document you have access to.

bullets: Search and filter by category, tags, dates, status and more
Select one, multiple, or all documents for bulk operations
Open the action menu for document-level operations
notes: You can select one, multiple, or all documents and use the bulk Share option to distribute them to users or groups in a single action.

cards.title: Document Action Menu (Quick Actions)
cards.why: Everything you can do with a document, in one place.

sheetTable.title: Document Actions
rows: Update name, description, or meta tags.
Grant access to users or roles.
Generate a public or password-protected link with optional expiry.
Generate an instant AI summary of the document.
Open the document in the built-in viewer.
Add an updated file — original is preserved.
View, restore, or download previous versions.
Add or read threaded comments on the document.
Set a date-based reminder tied to this document.
Send the document as an email attachment.
Apply a text watermark across all PDF pages.

notes: Render these actions as a horizontal card switcher. Clicking an action card opens its detail. Also provide a button: **Open as Table** → opens overlay sheet with the table above.

cards.title: Assigned Documents
cards.why: A focused view of what is assigned to you, with status and reminders.

body: Assigned Documents is your personal list of documents you are responsible for.
This view typically includes a Status dropdown and a My Reminders panel.
bullets: Each entry shows: name, status, category, creation date, expiration date, created by
Use status updates to track progress

cards.title: Archived Documents
cards.why: Keep older documents available without crowding active lists.

body: Archived documents remain accessible for reference and history, while staying out of the active workspace.

cards.title: Expired Documents
cards.why: Prevent outdated files from being used in active processes.

body: Expired documents are automatically flagged by the system. This prevents outdated versions from being used in active processes.

cover.intro: Upload documents, manage versions, and keep context through comments.
takeaways: Upload single files or bulk upload
Version History preserves originals
Comments keep decisions traceable
Status/visibility fields must be used consistently

cards.title: Adding a Document
cards.why: Create a document record with category, status and metadata.

notes: The Status field on the upload form controls access visibility (e.g., Confidential or Public). Separately, documents also carry a lifecycle status — Draft, Final, or Archived — managed via Document Status settings. These two controls are independent.

cards.title: Bulk Document Upload
cards.why: Upload multiple files efficiently while keeping them categorized.

steps: Start upload and wait for completion.
Review the uploaded documents in **All Documents**.
Fix any failed uploads and retry.

cards.title: Version History
cards.why: Track changes over time and restore older versions when needed.

stepsGroups.title: Upload a New Version
steps: Upload the replacement file; the original is preserved.

stepsGroups.title: View or Restore a Previous Version
steps: Choose a prior version to view or restore.

notes: Restoring a version keeps traceability: you can still access other versions later.

cards.title: Comments
cards.why: Capture collaboration context directly on documents.

body: Use threaded comments to discuss changes, approvals, and clarifications linked to the document.

cover.intro: Share documents securely, collaborate externally, and protect files with signatures and watermarks.
takeaways: Share to users/roles with duration controls
Shareable links can be password-protected
Email sending depends on SMTP settings
Signatures and watermarks create traceable outputs

cards.title: Share Document
cards.why: Grant access to users or roles for controlled collaboration.

steps: Select users and/or roles to share with.
notes: If Allow Email Notification is checked, SMTP must be configured. An error is shown if SMTP settings are missing.

cards.title: Shareable Link
cards.why: Share externally without creating an account for recipients.

notes: All options are optional — links can be as open or as restricted as needed. The recipient needs no account to access the document.

cards.title: Send as Email
cards.why: Send a document as an email attachment directly from the platform.

steps: Send the email and confirm delivery in logs if required.

cards.title: Digital Signatures
cards.why: Sign PDFs digitally and keep signed outputs consistent and secure.

steps: Place the signature and required fields.

cards.title: Document Watermarks
cards.why: Protect documents by applying a repeated watermark text across pages.

steps: Enter watermark text and apply to generate output.
notes: Every watermark action creates a new document version. The original is always preserved in version history.

cover.intro: Collect files from internal or external users without requiring accounts.
takeaways: Requests generate shareable upload links
Rules can limit file type and counts
Review submissions and approve/reject with comments

cards.title: Create a File Request
cards.why: Generate a controlled upload link for collecting documents.

steps: Configure rules and generate the request link.

cards.title: Review Submitted Documents
cards.why: Approve or reject submissions so quality stays consistent.

bullets: Reject with a clear reason (e.g., wrong file type, missing pages, unreadable scan)

cover.intro: Find documents by metadata and content — from quick lookups to deep content discovery.
takeaways: Standard Search filters library quickly
Deep Search scans inside file content
Results prioritize precision and relevance

cards.title: Standard Search
cards.why: Quickly filter by name, category, tags, and dates.

cards.title: Deep Search
cards.why: Search inside document content across supported file types.

bullets: Supported file types depend on system configuration
notes: Searching 'run' will also return results for 'running' and 'runs'. Common words like 'and', 'the', and 'is' are automatically excluded to improve precision.

cover.intro: Set time-based reminders tied to documents or tasks and receive notifications in-app and by email.
takeaways: Reminders can repeat on schedules
Notifications can be in-app and email
Email delivery depends on SMTP

cards.title: Reminders
cards.why: Schedule alerts for reviews, renewals, and follow-ups.

steps: Open the document action menu (or reminders area).

tables.title: Reminder Fields
rows: Title of the reminder (e.g., "Contract Review Due")
Daily / Weekly / Monthly / Semi-annually / Custom date
Also sends an email notification when triggered
Choose individuals or groups to receive the reminder

cards.title: Notifications
cards.why: Stay informed when documents are shared or reminders trigger.

notes: External users who receive shared documents are notified with a secure access link — no account required.

cover.intro: Automate multi-step processes with workflows, track status, and review logs.
takeaways: Create workflows to standardize approvals
Track running workflows and statuses
Logs provide traceability for each step

cards.title: Create & Manage Workflows
cards.why: Define repeatable processes so teams execute consistently.

stepsGroups.title: Create a New Workflow
steps: Define steps, assignees, and rules; then save.

cards.title: All Workflows
cards.why: See every workflow and its status across the platform.

notes: Graphical workflow views typically show completed transitions separately from pending transitions.
Steps can be clickable to view current assignee state and history.

cards.title: My Workflows (Current Workflows)
cards.why: A user-focused view of workflows you can act on.

notes: This page shows only the workflows you are personally authorized to manage or participate in — a focused, user-specific view.

cards.title: Workflow Logs
cards.why: Trace what happened, when, and by whom during workflow execution.

body: Workflow logs record the execution of workflows step-by-step, supporting troubleshooting and audit needs.

cover.intro: Generate documents, summarize files, and reuse templates to speed up repeat work.
takeaways: AI Generator creates documents from prompts
AI Summary compresses long documents instantly
Prompt templates standardize outputs
Deep Search complements AI workflows

cards.title: AI Document Generator
cards.why: Generate new documents from a prompt and refine outputs quickly.

steps: Write a clear prompt describing what you need.
Generate the output and review it.
Save or export the final document.
bullets: Tip: be specific about structure, audience, and required sections
Tip: include compliance or policy constraints directly in the prompt

tables.title: Common Issues
rows: Enter a valid prompt and check your connection.
Ensure you're logged in with a valid session.
Wait a few minutes and try again.

cards.title: AI Document Summary
cards.why: Get key points without reading the entire file.

body: Select any document already in your library and generate an instant AI summary from the document action menu.
Useful for reviewing lengthy files, quickly extracting key points, or onboarding team members to an existing policy or contract without reading the full document.

cards.title: Deep Search (Cross-reference)
cards.why: Find exact terms inside documents and connect discovery to AI tasks.

body: Deep Search is described in detail in Chapter 7 — Search.
Use it to locate content inside documents and then take action (share, summarize, workflow) from the results.

cards.title: AI Prompt Templates
cards.why: Standardize repeat AI outputs across teams and departments.

steps: Open **AI Prompt Templates** in the admin panel.
Create a new template with a clear name.
Save and reuse templates in AI generation flows.
notes: Administrators can create, edit, and delete templates from the admin panel. Templates support any number of named placeholders.

cards.title: AI Document List (History)
cards.why: Review what was generated and reuse outputs as needed.

bullets: Prompt field: stores what you asked the AI to produce
Output field: stores the generated result for review and reuse
body: Use this list to track what has been produced, compare iterations, and reuse successful outputs.

cover.intro: Configure categories, statuses, storage, extensions, SMTP, and in-app help content.
takeaways: Categories structure your library
Statuses define lifecycle states
Storage can be local or cloud
SMTP enables email sending and notifications

cards.title: Document Categories
cards.why: Keep the library organized and measurable.

steps: Save; then add subcategories as needed.
notes: Use subcategories to reflect departments, processes, or client structures.

cards.title: Document Status (Lifecycle)
cards.why: Define workflow lifecycle states such as draft/final/archive.

notes: Lifecycle status is separate from the access visibility field (Confidential / Public) set at upload. They control different things.

cards.title: Storage Settings
cards.why: Choose where documents are stored and whether encryption is used.

tables.title: Storage Types
rows: Default, cannot be deleted. Always available as a fallback.
Access Key, Secret Key, Bucket Name

notes: When you save a new configuration, the system uploads a test file to verify the connection. If the test fails, you are prompted to correct the settings before they are applied.

cards.title: Allowed File Extensions
cards.why: Control what file types users can upload for safety and consistency.

steps: Test by uploading an allowed and disallowed file type.

cards.title: Email (SMTP) Settings
cards.why: Enable email sending for sharing, reminders, and notifications.

steps: Save and set one configuration as default.
notes: Multiple SMTP configurations can be stored. Only the one marked as default is used automatically.

cards.title: Page Helpers (In-app Help)
cards.why: Maintain help text inside the platform for users.

bullets: Edit helper content to keep guidance current

media.caption: Admin settings area (includes helper content management)

cover.intro: Traceability and accountability for actions, logins, emails, and scheduled jobs.
takeaways: Audit trails support compliance reviews
Login logs track security events
Email logs help troubleshoot delivery
Cron logs reveal automation health

cards.title: Document Audit History
cards.why: See who did what to which document and when.

notes: Click any entry to view additional details or navigate directly to the associated document.

cards.title: Login Audit Logs
cards.why: Track authentication events and investigate suspicious activity.

cards.title: Email Logs
cards.why: Confirm what was sent, to whom, and whether delivery succeeded.

tables.title: Email Log Fields
rows: Unique identifier for each email sent
The email address the message was sent from
Any files included in the email
Sent / Failed / Queued / Delivered / Opened / Bounced
If delivery failed, the error reason is captured

cards.title: Cron Job Logs (Automation)
cards.why: A system automation audit trail for reminders, retention, and maintenance.

notes: This log acts as a system automation audit trail — valuable during compliance reviews and for troubleshooting notification delivery issues.

sheetTable.title: Scheduled Jobs
rows: Sends reminders on user-defined custom dates
Aggregates and dispatches daily document alerts
Recurring weekly reminders for document actions
Processes all queued outgoing emails reliably
Auto-deletes archived documents past their retention period
Applies retention rules: delete, archive, or expire
Cleans up old log records to maintain system performance

cover.intro: Automatic retention policies that keep storage organized and compliant without manual effort.
takeaways: Retention applies to archived documents
Auto-deletion triggers after the set period
Reduces clutter and supports compliance

cards.title: Archive Document Retention Period
cards.why: Automatically delete archived documents after a set time.

steps: Enable the retention setting and select a retention period.
The system monitors archived document age and auto-deletes once the threshold is reached.
notes: Enabling this feature helps keep your workspace organized and ensures compliance with data retention policies — without any manual intervention.

cards.title: End of Manual
cards.why: You’ve reached the end of the guide.

body: For additional support, contact your system administrator or use the in-app help content where available.
